newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times front page - April 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times front page - April 1.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following stories on its front page on Tuesday:
* The Supreme Court upheld a federal law requiring cable television systems to carry local broadcast station signals.
* Share prices tumbled for the second day, battered by concerns over whether the bull market could continue. The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 157.11 points to close at 6,583.48.
* People in the United States on welfare are getting jobs, but at the expense of the country's working poor.
* Clothes made in China are sent to retailers in the United States and Europe with "Made in Hong Kong" labels, in an attempt to circumvent European and American limits on Chinese textile imports.

* Nigerian Edwin Bulus who fled to the United States seeking asylum from his country's military dictatorship, has been held by immigration officials since his arrival at Kennedy International Airport in May 1995.
* Zaire's rebel leader Laurent Kabila has kept his plans for the country, and his own past, quiet.
* Officials said they were prepared to close an investigation into the death of 39 cultists in California, saying they had no evidence that a crime had been committed.
* A northeasterly storm swept through the New York area, and forecasters warned of strong winds and below-normal temperatures.
